everything now there are two approaches to dealing with accessibility um one of
the techniques that's used is the more traditional assistive technology a wheelchair is a good example of this uh
these are typically products or systems that are designed for a specific uh
capability or specific disability um they're very effective at delivering service but you have a niche product
problem and that many cases there's only one or two companies providing this particular technology because there's
such a small Market there's not enough people to buy it so you can't support a large industry so this has led to a number of
problems over the years in the in the accessibility Community where a lot of Technologies uh become orphaned because
the person who's uh behind that company is usually a one or two person company something happens in their lives and
they're no longer doing the business and so that product just disappears off the market uh and any research or any sort
of development that went into it is gone and so the funding agencies have become
increasingly concerned about this particular problem and so they Advocate a technique called Universal Design
wherever possible you still need assist of Technology that's critical but in some cases you can get by with what's
called Universal Design and Transit is a really good example of this so um back
in the day buses used to be high floor buses you used to have to climb the steps to get up in the bus school bus
are like this so city buses are like that in many countries they still are but in the United States you're seeing
more and more of them down at the low floor bus style and that's intentional for a number of different reasons um the
first and foremost is that people get on and off the bus faster because you're not climbing steps it's a lot safer
because people aren't tripping and falling out of the stairs down the stairs um but if you use a wheelchair
all of a sudden that means that the grade change is sign significantly smaller so with multiple steps you had
to essentially have a miniature elevator that would come out it's called a lift that would come out from the stairs and
raise a person up and bring them in these things are these really complex mechanical uh structures they break all
the time because it's a niche product Niche manufacturer Niche maintenance so the approach of low floor uh vehicles uh
makes the mechanism much smaller much simpler because you're only trying to do a grade change of a small amount and so
you can get by with a flip out a flip out ramp or or a telescoping ramp
and those sorts of systems survive uh abuse much better uh because they're simpler and so forth but what's also
happening is is you're seeing the same basic ideas in terms of providing space for a wheelchair in a bus to also be
used for providing space for other users as well so uh wheelchairs uh in many
vehicles the wheelchair space is also the same space that might get used by uh a stroller luggage a bicycle so forth um
other vehicles they they make it in separate spaces but but the idea is that Universal value to a lot of different
users um the other thing to keep in mind about Universal Design approaches is
that even if the vast majority of your user base does not have a disability there's still cases where they do have a
functional disability for that particular scenario so you know if it's a rainy dreary night and you've got your
hood up now of a sudden you have restricted peripheral vision in the dark you have restricted color perception so
all these different things start adding up and you essentially have a disability there's probably at least one bar here in town that keeps captioning on the TV
all the time because you can't hear the TV so that's an example of a scenario based disability and a number of you
probably ride your bikes with headphones on you can't hear a thing around you you're effectively deaf while you're
riding your bike so Universal Design helps solve these problems another core techniques that we

something as simple as uh failing to clear snow out of a bus stop and and resulting in an icy sheet around the the
bus the bus stop area and so these sorts of breakdowns are actually the source of
the vast majority of accessibility problems so we went through this process
um and came back with a a core approach that we wanted to pursue which is a co-design approach and the idea is that
uh the people who are using the public transit also could provide value to improve that Service delivery uh this

examples of co-production of value in a system where your end users are making that system more valuable and there's

the first is that if you're have a disability you want to know when the bus is going to show up I mean we all want
